title: 109_hr1870
content:
The "Disaster Recovery Act of 2005" allows for expedited payments of federal assistance for debris removal and emergency protective measures. The "Disaster Recovery Act of 2005" authorizes expedited payments of federal assistance to eligible applicants, including state and local governments, and private non-profit organizations, for disaster relief under specific sections of the Stafford Act. Payments must be made within 60 days of filing a claim for assistance. The term "eligible claim for assistance" refers to claims for debris removal necessary to eliminate immediate threats following an emergency or major disaster. This includes clearing, removing, or disposing of debris such as trees, sand, gravel, building components, wreckage, vehicles, and personal property. To address immediate threats to human life, public health, or safety, significant damage to property, and ensure economic recovery after an emergency or disaster, emergency protective measures may be taken. This includes providing temporary public transportation services in the affected community. Emergency protective measures are actions taken before, during, or after an emergency to eliminate threats to human life or property as determined by the Secretary of Homeland Security. Other claims may be considered appropriate by the Secretary. The terms "emergency" and "major disaster" are defined by the Robert T. Stafford Disaster and Emergency Assistance Act. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster and Emergency Assistance Act defines "emergency" and "major disaster" as per section 102(2). SEC. 3. Requirement to ensure debris clearance, removal, and disposal from emergency access roads. Reimbursement under the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief Act must cover clearing, removing, and disposing of debris from emergency access roads. An emergency access road is defined as a road needed by emergency personnel like firefighters and police. 

SEC. 4. Debris removal from private land is now eligible for federal assistance. Section 408(c)(2)(A) of the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act is amended to include the removal, clearance, and disposal of debris from private property resulting from an emergency or disaster.
